titleStmt.title: What spells do distant stars
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original document is in the public domain. Subject to certain exceptions, public domain works may be freely copied or used in the creation of derivative works without permission, or authorization, of the former copyright owners.

The text encoding was created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and is governed by a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

note.p: Drafts lines of "You Tides with Ceaseless Swell," first published along with seven other poems in The Nineteenth Century (August 1885), under the general title "Fancies at Navesink." On the verso is correspondence on the letterhead of Bim M. Jordan, Dry Paints, Pine Wood Products.

bibl.author: Whitman, Walt
bibl.title: Fancies at Navesink
bibl.orgName: Walt Whitman Literary Manuscripts in The Thomas Biggs Harned Collection of the Library of Congress
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.
The verso is made of two pasted together papers; one paper is blank and the other reflects correspondence to Walt Whitman written on the letterhead of Bim M. Jordan, Dry Paints, Pine Wood Products.

lg.l: What ye miracles of all the rest! ye tides do this work.
What first senseslanguages ya out you and calls ye back again.

l.del: (tr downWhat space endless, intermisticalintermystical look again through boundless space charms to sun and moon?

lg.l: What potent spells do distant suns send tostars shed on

What boundless aggregate, unseen and seen?
what compact law of all, space entire

Holding the universe entire and one, as sailing
in a ship?
